nodes.text: Social welfare can be maximized by choosing commodity taxes and public production so that aggregate production efficiency is desirable in many circumstances even when lump sum redistribution is impossible
Aggregate production efficiency is desirable as part of the social-welfare maximizing solution even when a full Pareto optimum cannot be achieved due to absence of lump sum taxes

With optimal commodity taxes present, marginal rates of substitution need not equal marginal rates of transformation (i.e., consumer price ratios differ from production slopes) in the decentralized optimum
When lump sum taxes are unavailable the income distribution implied by market outcomes is not the best conceivable, so commodity taxes will be used to alter real incomes for redistribution purposes

The planner's optimization problem is formulated using consumer prices q as control variables with constraint that aggregate demand X(q) belongs to production set G; using a Lagrangian yields first-order conditions characterizing optimality

From the Lagrangian first-order condition with multiplier lambda nonzero, equal marginal rates of transformation in public and private production follow, implying aggregate production efficiency (equation analogous to X(fk - gk)=0)

Optimal tax structure is given by first-order conditions relating marginal social utility of price changes to marginal tax revenue changes (expressions equivalent to vk = lambda sum p_i (d x_i / d q_k) and special form x_k^-1 d(t_k x_k)/dt_k = constant when welfare is individualistic)

The one-consumer analysis (geometric and algebraic) extends to many consumers: if indirect welfare V(q) and aggregate demand X(q) are continuous and mild conditions hold, optimal production lies on the production frontier (weak efficiency)

Constructed examples show exceptions: optima can be interior to production set (not weakly efficient) under special preference/endowment configurations, so efficiency is not an absolute necessity in all conceivable cases

Existence theorems: under standard assumptions (closed convex consumption sets, continuity and convexity of preferences, closed production set G, bounded attainable set) an optimum exists; Debreu results ensure attainable nonempty under further assumptions

Formal lemma/theorem: if at an optimum V(q) is locally monotone in some price direction (i.e., derivative not identically zero), then aggregate demand at the optimum lies on the frontier of G; when social welfare respects individual preferences and at least one household reacts, frontier solution follows

Extensions and implications: grouping nonconsumer sectors implies no optimal intermediate-goods taxes (to preserve efficiency); results extend to cases with regionally different consumer prices, tourism, and some international trade cases provided reactions of others are well-defined

Limitations and assumptions: key assumptions include constant returns and competitive private sector (no pure profits), availability of commodity taxes on all intersector transactions, continuity of aggregate demand and welfare, and lambda nonzero; violations (profits, restricted taxes, discontinuities) can invalidate efficiency conclusions
